Another amazing pixelated adventure!  There are so many different settings and scenes to explore, with such variety. 
 
These rival the old Sierra game and bring their own unique charm that makes for a whole new kind of experience.  They have paid attention to so many details...even as simple as the animation going up a lighthouse, makes it feel like 3D, having the character wrap around a set of spiral stairs, even just for a split second you can see it.

I have truly never seen people use pixel graphics is such a touching and beautiful way!  I found myself screen shooting a number of images that were so very expressive.

This is an awesome sequal to The Last Door...Again, you are immersed into a macabre world of mystery, with their excellent use of graphic design, music and sound, oh the sound (make sure to wear your headphones ;)!

Pure artistry and story telling.  Althought, there is a little bit more back and forth, running between the same location numerous times.  There are also some puzzles which simply solve themselves by you following very trivial clues, so I think they are a little less sophisticated than the previous.  Thus, more story, along with a bit more tedious.

It was a wonderful use of multiple characters to tell an entire story from different perspectives.  It allows you to connect with the story on different levels.

I honestly hope that we will see more of these from this developer!!!  Cannot wait for Blasphemous!


ACHIEVEMENTS:  The supposed "secrets" are way too obscure for any human being to find on their own, so you will need help on this one!

36681087.review:
Dopo il finale "aperto" della S1 di The Last Door, era chiaro che ce ne sarebbe stata un'altra e infatti eccola qui. Stavolta però a cercare di far luce sul destino di Devitt (il protagonista della S1) ci sono i suoi due psicoterapeuti, che come novelli Sherlock e Watson decidono di indagare sui terribili avvenimenti accaduti nella speranza di dare un senso a quanto sta succedendo.

Come la S1, anche la S2 è un'avventura grafica horror suddivisa in 4 episodi che iniziano esattamente dove l'altra si era conclusa. Le differenze con la S1 però sono evidenti: a parte il primo episodio, un po' breve e in linea con quanto visto in precedenza, gli altri sono decisamente più lunghi ed elaborati, non sono più confinati in una singola location ma mettono in scena delle vere e proprie mappe stile Monkey Island da cui poter raggiungere le varie zone (da sbloccare man mano raccogliendo gli indizi o le testimonianze).

Anche il gameplay ha fatto un deciso passo in avanti, con tanti enigmi intelligenti e complessi che tirano in ballo libri, quadri, statue, chiavi, indovinelli e chi più ne ha più ne metta, con il culmine raggiunto dal secondo episodio - di certo il migliore di tutta la serie. Mai niente di troppo impossibile, ma sufficiente per mettere in moto il cervello.

La stessa grafica vede un netto miglioramento rispetto al primo, del quale mantiene lo stile "fatto a Paint" ma presenta innanzitutto finalmente una risoluzione da persone normali (la S1 era fissa ai 4:3 per qualche ragione), un'eccellente gestione dell'illuminazione e tutta una serie di bellissime animazioni pixelate che vanno dall'intensa nevicata al fuoco che scoppietta nel camino, senza risparmiarsi in toni inquietanti e sanguinosi in più di un'occasione.

La trama come detto segue quanto accaduto nella S1 e si svolge bene anche qui, giungendo a una sorta di conclusione pur lasciando ancora qualche punto oscuro e facendo forse qualche giro di troppo tra i vari episodi, che a volte danno l'impressione di divagare attraverso nuovi miti e folclore che non hanno troppa attinenza con il filone principale della storia - non viene mai perso veramente di vista e in qualche modo si finisce sempre là, ma avrei forse preferito un percorso più chiaro e netto, senza tante deviazioni. 
A margine, se nella S1 si vedevano chiari rimandi a Poe, qui vengono quasi del tutto abbandonati in favore di ripetuti orrori lovecraftiani (non che mi lamenti).

Rimane ottima la colonna sonora di piano e violino, gli effetti sonori d'atmosfera e altrettanto buona la traduzione italiana, sempre in linea con quanto visto nella S1.

L'aumento della lunghezza e della complessità degli episodi aumenta senz'altro anche la longevità: dai 30-40 minuti a episodio della S1 si passa senza problemi a più di un'ora per ciascuno, specialmente quelli più intricati, per una durata totale di circa 5-6 orette per arrivare in fondo. 
La rigiocabilità non è altissima neanche qui, c'è un breve finale alternativo e una dozzina di segreti da trovare (sempre impossibili senza una guida), ma a differenza della S1 merita di più il prezzo pieno.

導入から既に前作のネタバレになってしまうので筋書きは避けてのレビューになりますが、シーズン1の先の読めないラストから巧く繋げてあり、とても感情移入して楽しめました。また短編集の趣きのあった前作に対し、盛り上がり・ボリューム共に大きく拡充され、続編に相応しいものとなっています（連作でトーンダウンしてしまうものも少なくない中で、これは充分に驚くべきことだと思います）。骨格としては同じく全4章ですが、それぞれにマップ移動の要素が加わり、だいたい二倍弱のプレイ量になっているのではないでしょうか。

謎解きに一部パズル色のあるものが見られるかなという部分もありますが、本当に突拍子もないものではなく裏付けのあるものになっていますし、この程度なら人によっては誤差範囲かもしれません。

36265488.review:
I enjoyed it a lot more than the first season. I might have just got used to its conventions, but I prefer to believe there were actual improvements on the development team's side. For one thing, Season 2 contains some actual well-thought-out puzzles (especially in the riddletastic Episode 2). I also found the mystery storyline (however commonplace and cliché-ridden) much more engaging, with some genuinely tense moments.

I still hold that the extra-blocky pixel art aesthetic works against the aims this game otherwise sets out to achieve. The characters come off as cute retro gamey people rather than tragic Victorian heroes facing unspeakable horrors. Point-and-clicking is little fun when you cannot discern what it is you're pointing and clicking at. That being said, I appreciated the skilfully done cutscenes, well-composed and animated despite the limitations of low resolution.

I had to consult the walkthrough a couple of times to find solutions I would never come up with on my own (which of course I'm going to ascribe to their unintuitiveness rather than my own intellectual limitations). A few puzzles felt wonky and badly designed; the maze was a particularly unfun throwback to the adventure genre's beginnings. I'm willing to forgive these flaws, however, considering the amount of times everything went just smoothly.

Since I have a soft spot for dreamlike or nightmarish imagery and logic, I enjoyed the last episode immensely. I would say it was worth playing through both seasons just to get to that experience. 

Make no mistake, The Last Door: Season 2 is neither a stunningly great adventure game nor a particularly good example of a cosmic horror tale (I was quite surprised to learn that the series seems to have an actual fan following, with people talking enthusiastically about its "lore" and supposedly-intriguing storyline). I do recommend it, however, since it sits just above the average and did manage to provide a pleasant distraction for a couple of hours.

36074983.review:
Pierwszy sezon zaskoczył mnie całkowicie. Trafiłem na niego przypadkiem i okazał się o wiele lepszy niż mógłbym przypuszczać. A muzyka już całkowicie kupiła moją duszę. Nie jest więc tajemnicą, czy zaskoczeniem, że po kontynuacji spodziewałem się przynajmniej takiego samego poziomu. Niestety, pomimo, że grę polecam, muszę przyznać, iż jest ona znacznie słabsza od poprzedniczki.

Nie będę wyjaśniał, czym The Last Door: Season 2 jest, gdyż, najprawdopodobniej, jeżeli to czytasz, to znaczy, że przeszedłeś sezon pierwszy. Więc: nic się nie zmieniło, to dalej klasyczna przygodówka point'n'click. Jednak tym razem sterujemy terapeutą bohatera, z którym mieliśmy sposobność zapoznać się w poprzedniczce.

Jednak to co najbardziej się zmieniło, to klimat. Gdzieś po drodze zniknął. Może spowodował to fakt, iż wiele się wyjaśnia, ale nie czuć już zaszczucia ani grozy. Dalej czuć tajemnicę wiszącą w powietrzu. Ale nie ma już uczucia czyjegoś wzroku na naszych plecach. Nie zrozumcie mnie źle: dalej są momenty, gdzie miałem przyspieszone tętno, jednak nie ma już takich, jak np króliki po przeczytaniu listu w jedynce - scen, gdzie byłem tak zmrożony, że nie mogłem się ruszyć.

Jednak to co mnie boli najbardziej - to muzyka. Sezon 1 miał rewelacyjny soundtrack. Słucham go do dziś i za każdym razem trąca on odpowiednie struny mojej duszy. Jednak sequel już "tego czegoś" jest pozbawiony. Większość kawałków jest praktycznie bliźniaczo podobna. Tak naprawdę w pamięci zapadł mi jedynie The Waltz Of H-A. Cała reszta rozmywa się do tego stopnia, iż nawet nie jestem w stanie wskazać fragmentów, w których dany kawałek leciał.

Jeżeli chodzi o fabułę - dalej trzyma poziom. Z tym, że jak wspominałem, tym razem dużo rzeczy się wyjaśnia i historia spotyka swe zakończenie. Jest to zdecydowanie jedna z najlepszych historii jakie znam. Do tego stopnia dobra, że w pewnym momencie całą oprawę graficzną zaczyna robić wyobraźnia i można całkowicie się zatracić w wiktoriańskiej Anglii. Dalej, troszkę mniej niż część pierwszą, ale polecam także tą. Naprawdę warto otworzyć akurat te drzwi.

35198845.review:
[h1]Short version: 77%[/h1]
The second season of The Last Door relies less on keeping the player shrouded in mystery and more on revealing some of its secrets through a more traditional adventure game setting. This small shift in focus still cannot harm its excellent atmosphere and storytelling mechanics.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Lovecraftian style suspense horror that relies on the primordial fear of the unknown is a dangerously complex subject, yet a small Spanish development team managed to tackle it with The Last Door, a game that invited us on an eerie, surreal journey beyond the world of reason.

This kind of atmosphere is difficult to keep up; this is probably why Season 2 chose a different approach. It is more of a straight-line point ‘n’ click adventure game now with all the associated staples, like collecting all movable everyday items to involve them in some needlessly overcomplicated task. As a result, the dread-inducing atmosphere only pops up during cut-scenes, chiefly at the beginning and at the end of each episode—except for the last one, that is dreary from start to finish.

Just like in Season 1, the pixel graphics provide only a vague representation of the game world, so our own imagination has to fill in the blanks, creating an even more powerful effect. The plot itself chooses a similar approach: we get many answers to our questions through the eyes of our new protagonist and the story has a definite ending, but there are enough questions left to leave the door slightly open for any potential new entries in the series. And this is exactly how a suspense horror story should be.

Me gustó mucho la primera temporada: una aventura gráfica sencillita, con muy buena ambientación y un tono fantástico lovecraftiano.

Esta segunda entrega es bastante más mundana, con unos secretos menos místicos y puzzles enrevesados "porque sí". En la primera no recuerdo si tuve que usar guía, pero en esta cada dos por tres estoy mirando algo. 

O bien es algo obtuso, o hay que andar mucho de un punto del puzzle a otro, o quizá es un evento en el que no hay que resolver nada, sino simplemente ir a cierto sitio para activar una cutscene. He llegado hasta casi el final del capítulo 2 (de 4) y no me está enganchando nada.

34378224.review:
Très bonne suite où nous incarnons cette fois le docteur Wakefield, dont Devitt (le protagoniste de la première saison) était le patient. Wakefield va tenter par tous les moyens de retrouver la trace de son patient, ce qui l'amènera à travers le voile via "the last door".

L'ambiance "Lovecraftienne" est toujours très présente. Plus on avance dans le jeu, et dans le voile, et plus le fantasmagorique est présent. Comme dans la précédente saison, les graphismes pixel le sont pour moi un peu trop : en effet, l'absence totale de détail sur les visages des personnages (pas d'yeux ni de bouches) leur donne une face impassible, contradictoire avec les émotions qu'ils sont censés ressentir tout au long. Malgré les évènements, on n'a jamais l'impression que Wakefield prend peur. Dommage car l'ambiance est vraiment là, appuyée par une excellente bande son, mais des bruitages en revanche plutôt médiocres.

Bonne surprise, le jeu est traduit en français.

33820040.review:
I am left with the feeling that pixel graphics like those of this game somehow convey the horror atmospheres better than high budget productions do. Your imagination has to work in order to imagine details, and thus leaves a more vivid impression.
Or maybe it's just that, given the relative simplicity of the graphics, there is more work on the script. Though I'm not convinced that's what makes these two games so great. The graphic IS beautifully crafted. 
I loved these games. The pacing and duration of each chapter is just perfect for me, the characters are all interesting, the mysterious atmospheres lure you forward and the revelations don't disappoint. The lovecraftian element is predominant especially in this second season, and I love how it's dosed and presented: never too vulgar, always compelling you forward through the story. And the simplicity of the puzzles makes sure that you don't get stuck. I like that part. More challenging puzzles would have distracted me from the plot. 
I can't find anything to criticize. Except I'd love to see more stories like this by this game studios.
Great game.

33756692.review:
[h1] The Last Door es el juego de Lovecraft que nadie se atrevía a hacer. Una aventura [i]point and click[/i] de nicho que solo los amantes del terror cósmico y de las aventuras gráficas clásicas sabrán disfrutar [/h1]

   H.P. Lovecraft fue un genio autodidacta, disminuido por la enfermedad, las deudas y aún más [b]por los gustos de su época[/b]. Para una literatura todavía sujeta a la moralidad y a las certezas aparentes, su obra era fantasía de segunda categoría. A día de hoy, su trabajo ejerce una influencia nítida en la cultura, especialmente en los videojuegos. Y de entre todos ellos, [i]The Last Door[/i] despunta por su [b] pureza [/b]. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1118297344

	En un mercado dominado por los gráficos, [i]The Last Door[/i] se atreve con reservas, se atreve a [b]no mostrar[/b]. Su apartado artístico, malentendido como género "indie", muestra bruscos perfiles y bordes dentados que iluminan la [b]imaginación del jugador[/b]. Y es en ese momento cuando una mancha de píxeles, aparentemente [i] insignificante[/i], nos devuelve el horror dos veces más fuerte. Un juego de apariencias que plasma como ningún otro la experiencia del [b]terror cósmico[/b].  

   Sin embargo, ahora hablamos de un videojuego, y esta forma de narrar también tiene sus limitaciones. Y es que en ocasiones encontraremos dificultades para [b]distinguir objetos interactivos[/b] con la mera observación, obligándonos a barrer el escenario con el ratón una y otra vez; y tampoco nos libramos de tramos particularmente [b]lentos[/b] que entorpecen el ritmo. Aquí la deliberada ambigüedad del juego se vuelve en nuestra contra; lamentablemente, este es el precio de la cuidada atmósfera del juego.

   Y si hablamos de una aventura point and click hablamos de puzzles, un apartado satisfactoriamente resuelto en [i]The Last Door[/i]. Los rompecabezas son disfrutables, con multitud de secretos y puntuales picos de dificultad que recuerdan a los clásicos del género.  Mención aparte merece la [b]fantástica banda sonora[/b] firmada por el español Carlos Viola. Ella por sí sola justifica el precio del juego completo, es alucinante.

[h1]Conclusión: [/h1]

   [i]The Last Door[/i] es una apuesta poco convencional para los estándares del mercado. Su narrativa exige al jugador una mente [b] libre de prejuicios[/b],porque [i]The Last Door[/i] nunca muestra, [i] sugiere[/i]. Por eso estás ante [b] una joya de culto [/b] alejada del gusto general. Así que si te convence su premisa no te la puedes perder. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1118296088
[h1] Nota final: 9/10[/h1]

33740503.review:
Working title: The Last Door: Season 2: The Awakening: The Resurrection: The Rebirth - Collector's Edition - Complete Edition - srorriM: Game of the Year Edition: The game.

Warning: This review contains spoilers for The Last Door: Season 1. If you haven't played the the first game... Well, why the heck are you reading the reviews for the second one?

The Last Door: Season 2 is a point and click horror game which follows doctor Wakefield as he investigates the disappearance of his patient, Jeremiah Devitt, who entered the veil with his childhood friend Alexandre. Wakefield must travel through England with his friend Kaufmann, as they find out more about the four witnesses and strange experiments with the intent of going beyond the veil.

The gameplay is very similiar to the first game - it's still walking around, picking up objects and solving puzzles, but this time, you have the option to travel around to different locations, making this game longer and more complicated than the first one. In my opinion, the puzzles are still very good, but it's easier to get stuck in this one and it's very likely that you will end up using a guide.

The story of this game is, in my opinion, even better than that of the first game. You play as Devitt's psychiatrist, doctor Wakefield, who teams up with his friend Johan Kaufmann to investigate Devitt's mysterious disappearance. Soon enough, you're haunted both by the mysterious force that haunted Devitt in the first game - the eye of the bird, and a mysterious organization called the Playwright. The game answers all the questions you had left after the first game and ties it all into a very satisfying ending. 

The horror aspect of the game was still very strong, with very original scares, psychological horror, great suspense and many interesting characters with chillingly disturbing stories. I thought that the first game was creepier, with scares sometimes being very unpredictable, but I didn't feel disappointed in this one, as it manages to deliver the spooks pretty well.

The pixel art has noticeably improved - even though I thought that the first one was gorgeous already, this game is even better at setting the right atmosphere using colour palettes and there's plenty of very beautiful sceneries and designs in this game. The music was also very good at reinforcing the atmosphere. The intro music was the same (but the intro art was more beautiful) and the music was the same genre as in the first one, so, if you enjoyed creepy classical music in the first game, you're gonna like it again. Just as in the first game, the sound design is very good, with many sounds used to create suspense, the jumpscares were handled well and there's interesting use of audio channels.

For a completionist, this game gives you achievements for finding secrets. This is nearly impossible without a guide, but, with one, it should take you less than 10 hours. It's pretty short, but a good choice if you only want to get a higher percentage.

Overall, this game lives up to the first one quite well. You can play it for free online, so, if you're stingy, you might want to play this one for free or on sale, but I thought it was a very good purchase and I recommend it to everyone who liked the first game.

33263242.review:
Continúa la saga "The Last Door" ¡ahora con píxeles más gordos todavía! Esta vez, John Wakefield se verá involucrado en un pifostio de la leche con un montón de movidas raras, tipos chalados y velas encendidas por todos los rincones. Todo aderezado con montones de [i]chan chaaan!!![/i]. El resultado es similar a la primera entrega, ya que sigue el estilo cinematográfico, con [i]macguffins[/i] a mansalva, planos de cámara arriesgados pero efectivos y diálogos interesantes. Eso sí, como siempre, Ben Affleck actúa de manera pésima.
Si eres un flipado de las resoluciones 4k y todos esos rollos, éste no es tu juego, aunque te tengo que decir que los píxeles de este juego son tan descomunales que tuve que meterle una tarjeta gráfica con tecnología alienígena para poder calcular cada pixel. Es como si de tan simplón que es, le da la vuelta al marcador y se convierte en un juego que consume muchos recursos.
Los puzzles son sencillos, hasta tal punto que casi es un juego de los de Telltale, pero si te va el tema de Cthulhu y eres un melancólico de las aventuras de los 90, pues ya sabes. ¡A comprar!

32700784.review:
TL;DR: Great story with an amazing soundtrack. Buy this if you like a good horror story. 

(Slightly) More detailed version:

If you are fond of the first season, don't hesitate to buy this. The second season vastly expands the storyline from the first. It has some major improvements on the narrative, enriches the original story, and is even more thrilling than the first season alone. 

The soundtrack is once again, perfect. The ambient is classic and unsettling, adding a lot to the most simplistic graphic this game has to offer. 

This is a perfect example of a horror story told right. It does not rely on the cheap jump scares (although it is featured in several parts of the game) to horrify the players, but through effective story telling and creepy environment.

32416840.review:
I reviewed the 1st "season" and I can tell you that it'll be very very similar to this one. This is a fantastic point-and-click adventure game with a beautifully crafted atmosphere and creepy audio design. Both games were incredible and entertaining, so much so that I waited to play the 2nd one with my S/O while he experienced the 1st game. 
This game is very obviously inspired by E.A.Poe and HP Lovecraft, but in a tasteful way. The story is unique and not something I've really encountered before. It's executed and set up very well and going back to find the secrets that you missed the first time only shines a little more light on the story. The direction is pretty clear in both games and that provides a fairly fast-paced gameplay with an occasional challenge that might stump you for a little bit.
I very much enjoyed this series and I will be sure to recommend it to anyone who enjoys an atmospheric point-and-click game!

32396538.review:
The last door это классическая адвенчура с отличным сюжетом, атмосферой и отличной пиксельной графикой, второй сезон которой, как мне кажется, вышел даже лучше первого.

Сюжет продолжается с конца 4 главы первого сезона, однако соприкасаются они достаточно слабо, играем мы здесь за доктора Кауфмана и его коллегу Уэкфилда, Девитт из первой части встречается здесь лишь в последней главе, так что если начать прохождение с этого сезона, то сюжет понять можно, но все же первый сезон лучше не упускать.
Локации в игре шикарные, они более разнообразны, чем в первом сезоне, где было больше помещений и почти не было открытой местности, также добавлена система с перемещением по карте.
Хоррор составляющая присутствует, однако уклон здесь больше в сюжет, но напугать игра также может.
Что касается геймплейной части, головоломки очень неплохие, есть над чем подумать и с логикой действий проблем почти не возникает.
Но самое главное, что есть в данном квесте - атмосфера, особенно во второй и третьей главе, прекрасный саундтрек также способствует этому.
В игре четыре главы и особенно мне понравилась вторая и третья, первая глава также на уровне, а вот четвертая(восьмая, учитывая четыре главы из первого сезона) и финальная глава для истории, вышла слабой, она должна была ответить на вопросы, но лишь задала новые, в странных флэшбэках я едва уловил нить сюжета, однако не могу сказать, что концовка совсем плоха, остались вопросы, но история завершена и продолжение не напрашивается.

В итоге могу сказать, что это просто отличный квест и достойное продолжение первой части, атмосфера отличная, сюжет интересный, хоть местами он и не совсем понятен, а отличный пиксель-арт радует глаз.
Оценка 9/10 лишь за слабую финальную главу, где не раскрыли большинство сюжетных моментов [spoiler]Особенно про чудовище в пещере и птицелюдей[/spoiler], да, некая загадочность должна оставаться, но здесь с этим перебор.
Очень рекомендую к покупке, если вы уже прошли первый сезон, особенно если вы любите адвенчуры с хорошим сюжетом и вас не пугает пиксельная графика.

32263759.review:
[b]The Last Door: Season 2 - Collector's Edition  4/5: [/b] V zásadě nemlich to samé co vynikající první sezóna obohacená o to, že tvůrci snaživě adresují její vůbec největší zádrhel; a to sice přílišnou přímočarost adventurních prvků a z toho plynoucí neexistující výzvu. Přesto je to o něco horší první části. Důvod je prostý. Tam kde první díl stavěl (a pevně stál) na podmanivé atmosféře skvostně vystavěného gotického horroru, kde co kapitola, to jedna pečlivě zrealizovaná lokace. Tentokrát se to vydalo cestou mnoha menším různorodých lokací. A tak namísto trávení celé kapitoly v znepokojivé lokalitě nemocnice, se podíváme na více lokací o méně obrazovkách. Rozmanitost na úkor celistvosti a sevřenosti.

 Což je ještě podtrženo výrazně rozdílnými horrorovými stylizacemi jednotlivých kapitol. Nikoli vizuálně, kdy stále platí, že pod rouškou zdánlivé vizuální ohyzdnosti se skrývá promyšlená a záměrná stylizace „naznačovaného neukázaného zla“. Ovšem zpět k rozdílnému pojetí kapitol, kdy se jedna nese ve stylu lovercraftovského plíživého šílenství a jiná variuje (původního!) Wicker Mana (a sama o sobě je nejlepší pasáží). Na druhou stranu nelze popřít, že jedna každá z kapitol má díky tomu svůj ksicht a specifickou atmosféru. Ovšem jako celek to pospolu dvakrát moc neštymuje. Což o jedničce platilo bezezbytku.

 Čistě po herní stránce je to tentokrát o chlup staré vypelichané krátkosrsté čivavy těžší i delší (stále se však bavíme o sotva pěti až šesti hodinách) a nesporně jde o pravověrnější adventuru než posledně; více nepřímočarých puzzlů, předmětů, kombinování apod. Výsledkem je tedy opět kvalitní žánrový titul a nesporně důstojné zakončení historie (ne)jednoho všeobjímajícího šílenství ve viktoriánské Anglii.

Oyunun henüz ilk bölümünü bitirdim fakat... Güzel bitirdim.
Bu sezonu oynuyorsanız zaten The Last Door'un olayını biliyorsunuzdur (ya da, bilmiyorsunuzdur :doorman: )
Hikayeye hızlı bir başlangıçla yumuluyoruz. Bu defa, stüdyonun biraz para bulması da işin içine girince, çok daha hoş müzikler, sahneler ve "anlatım türleri" ile karşılaşıyoruz. Müzik ve sahnelere diyecek lafım yok. Fakat, hikayenin verilişi, ana karkaterin değişmesinden dolayı mıdır bilemem, bana önceki sezonu özletti. Belki ileride değişecektir. Gene de, mevzuatın kendisi esrarengizliğinden ve sürükleyiciliğinden bir şey yitirmiş değil. 31886650.review:
Parte final del videojuego [u][url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/taizo_hori/recommended/284390]The Last Door - Collector's Edition[/url][/u] que sirve como continuación inmediata a los acontecimientos desarrollados en la  temporada anterior del susodicho. En este nuevo contenido nos podremos en el papel del doctor John Wakefield, el psiquiatra que trataba las dolencias de Jeremiah Devitt, el protagonista de la anterior temporada [spoiler] y que en vistas de su desaparición tras relatarle sus extrañas vivencias decide ir en su busca para esclarecer finalmente el misterio que rodea esta apasionante trama.[/spoiler]

El juego se desarrolla con los mismos pretextos expuestos en la primera parte sin añadir cambio alguno a sus mecánicas ni a jugabilidad, por lo tanto encontramos unos controles basados nuevamente en el “point and click” con escenarios de avance lateral 2D, gráficos de estética pixel art y banda sonora instrumental, todo en la perfecta escala que nos ofreció la primera parte.

Como notas a destacar cabe mencionar que aunque el contenido se presenta correcto y da fin a la trama que inició el anterior capítulo de esta saga, esta no ofrece la calidad ni el desarrollo esperado, pues aunque decente no llega a la altura de la primera parte dejándonos un sabor agridulce en diferentes aspectos, tales como la escena de terror, que pasa a desaparecer prácticamente en su totalidad, la calidad de la banda sonora, que aunque decente no es tan buena como la primera  temporada y por último y más importante el argumento, que finaliza bastante precipitadamente y deja bastantes cabos sueltos.

En definitiva, una continuación algo desmerecida pero que por otra parte no deja de ofrecer lo que se busca, un final para la trama y una experiencia continuada de lo que ya disfrutamos anteriormente, también cabe mencionar que es recomendable adquirir esta temporada en pack junto con la primera y con descuento, puesto que su duración no es equiparable a su precio por separado, no obstante no por esto deja de ser un producto de calidad, bien acabado y sin fallos aparentes, aunque nos hace pensar al respecto de la necesidad de seccionar el argumento en dos temporadas, aún así no puedo dejar de recomendarlo a aquellos que jugaron a la primera parte y desean concluir la historia. Interesante pero no brillante.

31792899.review:
Con esta segunda entrega se cierra el arco argumental de Last Door. Y a mi parece lo hacen muy satisfactoriamente. 

Sigo pensando que la elección de pixel-art con píxeles grandes como puños es una verdadera lástima. No me gustaron en la primera temporada y siguen sin gustarme en la segunda. Esta vez, al menos, puedes poner resoluciones de pantalla menores (800x600 por ejemplo) y así al menos distinguir un poco mejor lo que hay en la escena. 

Da igual. Aquí hemos venido por la historia y, pese a los píxeles como ladrillos, la inmersión es completa. Es como estar metidos en un buen relato de Lovecraft o Derleth. La historia va desarrollándose muy lentamente, con más misterios que respuestas, pero en su última escena los compases encajan y dejan un satisfactorio regustín de haber jugado a algo que ha valido la pena. Resuelve la trama principal pero deja los suficientes huecos como para que puedas intuir otras tramas secundarias. Es de esos guiones que no abundan en el mundo de los videojuegos, de los que se toman en serio a los jugadores.

Aunque se ha realizado un excelente trabajo de guión, con una historia envolvente y unos personajes bien construidos, la parte de la jugabilidad no me ha parecido tan satisfactoria. Los puzzles son fáciles y, de alguna manera, me parecen un poco forzados. Es como si estuvieras leyendo un libro muy interesante y de pronto todo se parase en seco para meter la jugabilidad. Puede ser porque las pistas sobre la utilidad de los objetos son tan sutiles como una motosierra. Me pasó algo parecido en 'Silent Age'. Claro que si los puzzles fueran muy difíciles el relato no tendría ese ritmo continuo. Reconozco que es más fácil criticar que dar una posible solución.

Punto y aparte es la música de Carlos Viola. Increíble. Si tenéis Spotify os recomiendo que os marquéis sus dos discos con la OST. De hecho hay un par de capítulos donde la música es escasa y se siente una menor inmersión de la historia. Es de esos juegos donde la música hace un trabajo que sólo notas cuando se detiene. También los efectos de sonido están muy bien escogidos. Pocos pero precisos.

En fin. Una videoaventura que me ha gustado mucho, con una historia bien trazada y que me ha mantenido atento desde el primer hasta el último capítulo. ¡Pues claro que la recomiendo!

31478269.review:
For a game that employs such simple graphics and mechanics, The Last Door managed to be scary, suspenseful and compelling. Hats off to the writers, devs and community of fans who made this little puzzle gem possible! Particular kudos has to go to the sound designers and composers, since so much of the terror of The Last Door comes down to what you hear rather than what you see (or DON'T see, in many cases). I know I'm not the only one who'll be haunted by a particular piano theme for a long time to come...

All that said, a few of the puzzles were unintuitive enough that I know I couldn't have figured them out without walkthroughs (and a couple I managed on sheer luck). I admit I'm not a top-notch puzzle gamer, so some of that is down to my own ineptitude. However, more clarity in some of the puzzles and "levels" would have made the game more enjoyable and seamless.

30842349.review:
The Last Door: Season 1 was described as a "journey to the brink of madness" and "a love letter to H.P. Lovecraft".  I agreed with this and Season 2 is no different.  The themes are clearly Lovecraftian and even as a story driven point and click game, it offers enough of a challenge and some great secrets to make it more than just a "click here to progress" adventure game.  

Like Season 1, Season 2 is not "terrifying", but it has that feeling of dread and the score really adds to the tension.  Over the course of the episodes you can feel it all building up.  The graphics are the definition of pixel art, but it''s actually a beautiful game with some amazing locations and cutscenes on offer.  Though this means that some objects are still difficult to locate as they blend in with the background a little too well.  Fortunately these moments didn't become frustrating.  

So it's a fantastic entry in the series, with a really interesting story that warrants more than one playthrough.  Like Season One, you should at least pick this up on sale if you want a great horror atmosphere, a few interesting puzzles and a brilliant soundtrack.

30581926.review:
这篇评测充满了个人主观想法，可以说是一则信仰评测。相较于第一季我更喜欢第二季所以就选择第二季来进行评测。这个游戏集齐了我充满中二病和腐朽气息的浪漫主义思想，1880的英国，洛式恐怖，爱式浪漫（？），[spoiler]神级别的[/spoiler]低像素，相当精致的背景音乐...唯一的不足在我看来大概是超低像素的小人容易使人脸盲。

游戏整体很好的营造了洛式恐怖的氛围，适量的jump scare，更多的是一种对于“未知的恐惧”的氛围营造。如果说第一季的主角devitt对整个事件还是有所了解的话第二季的主角醒田就完全是两眼一抹黑的好奇心以及责任感使然的调查员形象了。游戏精细的支线设置也让整个世界观更加真实且厚重，印象最深的是第二章的lost in the sea成就支线。以下是剧透[spoiler]这个支线描述了一对1890年代下的生死相隔les情侣的苦情故事，体弱多病的女子（对不起我真不知道她叫啥我只知道她爱人叫rose）请求醒田帮她去墓地献花，只提供了carter的姓氏，而到达墓地时却发现只有一位叫做rose carter的女性姓carter，醒田对此做出的反应只是...，某种意义上也是一位很开明且善良的医生呢。在海边捡到rose的挂坠也会将其交还给那位姑娘，而最终在洞窟中发现rose的骸骨，亦是让人唏嘘。怎么讲呢，恐怖游戏里情侣就是个flag，管你政治正确不正确都得死。[/spoiler]剧组在相当有限的探索向剧情里对醒田的人物形象的塑造也是很丰满的，至少在结束整个游戏之后我能感受到醒田是个兼顾责任感，好奇心，充满同理心以及意志坚定的医生，即使有时会相当依赖自己的好朋友烤麸，但是不论遇到多么恐怖掉san的事情也会坚持自己的决定。[spoiler]而全球的成就统计中，达成了拯救devitt的成就人数较拯救醒田的人要多，想必大家也是很成功地代入了这个角色，至少我觉得这就是他会做的事情。[/spoiler]

游戏难度并不高，大家都知道这个point click game我就不多介绍啥了，支线很少，全成就其实还是有点麻烦的，尤其是全秘密收集，很多条件很迷幻，需要你站在原地等待事件触发，对我这种没有耐心的玩家来讲有点煎熬。但是这仍然是我玩过的最容易达成全成就的游戏之一。游戏中有很多文学梗，尤其是两位爱老的（爱伦坡和爱手艺），就我印象里有第一季第一章有爱伦坡的黑猫捏他，第四章则是有诗歌乌鸦中的“nevermore”捏他，第一季第二章的圣高尔原寄宿学校现医院的床头柜上则有爱手艺曾经投稿过的杂志weird tales（虽然据我考究这个时间线有点不对头，就当是单纯的玩梗好了）。还有更多的梗我就不在这里做过多陈述了，wikia上都可以找到。[spoiler]官方商店还有两位爱老的像素头像T恤，不是很懂你们官方在想什么。[/spoiler]

总之这游戏可以说是我最喜欢的恐怖游戏之一，如果你和我一样热爱洛式恐怖以及上面提到的各种标签（懒得再打一遍），我强力向你们推荐这部作品。

29954708.review:
The fearful conclusion to the Last Door picks up where season one left off. Without spoiling too much, you play an acquaintance of the protagonist from the first season following a trail of clues to unravel the mystery of the Veil. 

TLD season 2 features the same level of graphics, low difficulty, and cryptic story as the first season along with a few spooks here and there and wraps the whole thing up within about 5 hours of gameplay. If you’re considering this game it means you’ve probably played the first one and want some closer.

As for the entire series, recommending it is tricky since it’s really story-heavy and not particularly challenging at all, though the same could probably be said of telltale games’ point and click adventures so I guess you could say this one is par for the course. I give it a reluctant thumbs-up for people wanting to scratch that point and click adventure itch but have tried everything else already.

29586121.review:
Esta segunda parte retoma la historia en el punto exacto donde se quedó la anterior aventura y le pone punto final a los acontecimientos que nos narra The Last Door y resuelve muchos de los misterios que se quedaron abiertos. Aunque no todos...

Un punto final que los creadores del juego pueden reabrir cuando quieran porque aunque la trama que afecta a los personajes de The Last Door queda bien cerrada, la profundidad de la idea y el hecho de que hayan quedado flecos sueltos permiten que todavía se puedan contar muchas más cosas del "Universo The Last Door". 

El tiempo dirá. 

Por lo demás nos encontramos con una aventura totalmente continuista con la anterior entrega. Y no solo me refiero a la trama de la narración, también hablo del apartado visual, la jugabilidad, la estupenda ambientación... y si, de los pixeles como puños que hacen sangran los ojos.

Se le aprecia un intento por presentar una aventura más desarrollada que en la primera entrega, con una duración mayor, unos puzles más elaborados y la implantación de algunos mecanismos jugables típicos de las aventuras graficas mas tradicionales, pero en esencia sigue ofreciendo exactamente lo mismo que el primer The Last Door. 

Mucha ambientación, mucho pixel art y mucho homenaje a los clásicos del terror. No solo a Lovecraft y Poe, también hay claras reminiscencias a Machen, Bierce y otros. 

Y es que esta es la clave de ambos juegos. El amor por los autores clásicos del terror y recrear una historia propia de ellos. Hay aventuras mucho mejores, mucho más bonitas y trabajadas artísticamente, con puzles mucho más trabajados y satisfactorios... sin duda. Pero lo que no abundan son juegos como estos que dan mucho con muy poco. Sobre todo a aquellos que quieran ver. 

Y por cierto. Nuevamente, estupenda la ambientación y estupenda la banda sonora. Ya quisieran muchos juegos. 

El unico punto negativo que le veo es que deberia haber sacado la aventura en una unica entrega y no en dos sesiones y por capitulos, pero supongo que es el precio que hay que pagar hoy en dia para que algunos titulos indies se financien y logren ver la luz. 

Juego aceptable para curiosos y aficionados a las aventuras graficas en general. Imprescindible para aquellos que han soñado alguna vez con Carcosa y esperan pacientes el regreso de aquellos que se esconden detrás del velo...

¿ Por que enseñar cuando se puede insinuar ? ¿ Por que ser explicito cuando se puede seducir sugiriendo ?. 


8/10.

28776492.review:
Let me preface this by saying that I really enjoyed Season 1 of this creepy suspense macabre point-and-click adventure game. I was mad about it ending a cliffhanger, but what can you do. This season brings the finale of the story, and...well, it's an ending at least. Season 1 was about unraveling a mystery through the main character of Devitt, and this season you play as his doctor, Wakefield, trying to track him down. There should have been a lot more explanations as we drew closer to the ending, but it was one big "Mystery Box", with more and more mysteries and very little answers. They kept introducing new lore even in the final chapter and gave only the briefest few lines to explain what had actually happened over eight full chapters of the game. The result was that, when I watched the recaps from previous episodes, they were mentioning plot points that were never outright revealed, but that the devs had assumed they had made clear, but I had just played that chapter and my conclusions about what had happened during the very abstract, surreal or just not obvious actions in the story were VERY different from the recap. "What? That was all a dream? Where did it say that?" or "Wait, the townsfolk were doing what?" There was so much cool stuff going on, but so much of it just got shoved into too late in the story.

Pros:
+ The music is FANTASTIC. Also good sound design despite it not having any voice acting. Creepy singing, screams, squeaks...great atmosphere.
+ Great art. It's pixel graphics, but it's well done. The lack of detail makes your mind fill in the blanks. Can be either beautiful or downright creepy, or both.

Neutral:
~ Some episodes had great puzzles. Others had very abstract ones, where you had to do things that made no sense just to trigger the next area/event. 

Cons:
- Story was meh (see above). Too much buildup without enough satisfying explanation.

Overall: If you liked the first season, it's probably worth it to buy it, if only to finish off the story. Or if you like semi-unresolved mysteries, this one also fits the bill. Or if you just like macabre point-and-click adventure games. 7/10

26507396.review:
La entrada original podéis encontrarla en 

https://thepastisnow.net/2016/11/07/the-last-door-season-2-viajes-a-el-otro-lado/

La primera temporada me encantó, tanto que no pude esperar a hacerme con la segunda para dejarme llevar por esta magnífica aventura de horror point and click.

En esta ocasión, y respetando la línea argumental de la primera temporada, el personaje principal es el doctor Jhon Wakefield, psiquiatra de Devitt, quien se desplazará por diferentes lugares, a través de 4 capítulos, en busca de su paciente y amigo.

Las historias narradas, junto con la banda sonora, te meten de lleno en la historia.
La trama es muy fuerte en este título, para mí además más fuerte que en la primera temporada, es más compleja, incluye más personajes, más lugares, una estructura muy bien enlazada y es más aterradora.

Desde el principio del juego, desde que vi la primera imagen, me gustó que la estética 8-bit en este caso está mejor conseguida, se entiende todo mucho más que en la primera entrega y además, da la sensación de que juegan mejor con este tipo de gráficos aprovechando su sencillez.

Digno de un relato de Lovecraft. Inquietante.

¡Algunas imágenes no las sacaras de tu cabeza!
Algunas escenas llegan a agobiarte, entre que ves poco, no sabes que está ocurriendo y la intriga de ver que está apareciendo algo y no sabes que es, consigue que en muchas escenas pases miedo más real de lo que piensas mientras lees este blog.

Destaco “La isla de Ellis Mor” como la parte que más he disfrutado, tanto lo que ocurre en esta isla, como sus pantallas son muy buenas, me gustan mucho las historias de terror, y Ellis Mor es un sitio perfecto para llevar a cabo muchos relatos.

Sabiendo que “el Dramaturgo” buscaba “la Verdad última” que era lo que tenia a Devitt obsesionado, experimentando en el colegio encontraron a un guardián aterrador… No puedo contar más, no quiero desvelar esta maravilla de juego, pero si os puedo decir que cierra el ciclo perfectamente y jugando te sentirás completamente  dentro de la atmósfera que han logrado transmitir, más de un salto vas a dar en tu silla, créeme.

La música es esencial en la intro.
La música es espectacular, Carlos Viola vuelve a darnos una magnífica banda sonora, que acompaña con unos efectos de sonidos muy buenos, de verdad, solo la intro, es digna de una serie de AMC o HBO, tanto las imágenes como la intensidad de la música, de hecho, siempre estoy esperando al terminar un capítulo que entre la banda sonora de cabecera, muy muy buena, me la regalaron en la versión de Steam, y la llevo en el coche!

 La resolución y la estética 8-bit están mejor conseguidas.
 
Una cosa si me he encontrado que me ha sabido mal, hay un par de fallos en el texto que aparecen al describir algunos objetos, es algo que debo comentar porque están ahí, no se si es mi versión, si es algo puntual o que esté corregido, aunque si os digo que no consiguen dejarte un mal sabor de boca, pero es algo que en la primera temporada no me ocurrió en ningún momento y estropea un poco la atmósfera de juego.

Como en la primera temporada, el juego sale a la luz gracias al apoyo de crowdfunding a través de Kickstarter, que ellos han sabido destacar y que incluso algunos de los que apoyaron, participaron en la descripción de algunos objetos, muy buen detalle que dice mucho de los chicos de The Game Kitchen.

 

La fotografía del juego es muy buena, la composición es muy buena y se nota que este aspecto está bien trabajado y cuidado, ganan mucho con las composiciones de este tipo que consiguen la inmersividad total, escenas donde hay nieve te darán sensación de frío, con una chimenea sensación cálida, soledad y terror, también consiguen traspasar la pantalla del ordenador, os dejo una galería con algunas imágenes que mas me han gustado.

Como comenté en la entrada de la primera temporada, conocí el título a través de la RetroSevilla, sin embargo en la edición de este año, no vi nada sobre el juego, aunque también entiendo que se lanzó en Enero y el evento fue a final de Octubre, pero claro, como me han dejado este hype, y han conseguido que me quede pendiente de futuras publicaciones, el “Wakefield” que llevo dentro tenía ganas de verles para poder preguntar cuando sale otro relato de terror tan fantástico.

¿Y tú? ¿Estarás dispuesto a cruzar “La puerta” aunque no sepas como volverás?

Nos vemos pronto!!!

Videte ne quis Sciat.

26364100.review:
Since you're here, I assume you already have an opinion about LD: Season 1.

In summary, I liked it a lot better than the first season. The episodes are longer and very generously fleshed out. The main character is now Dr. Wakefield, which, in my view, helped a lot with the story pacing, which is now much more straightforward and less cryptic (for the fans of ambiguity, fear not, there's still a whole lot of it). The first three episodes of S2 are extremely well done, adding map travel and a micronarrative element to the already very atmospheric environments of the first game. The last episode follows the classic format, tying the story together nicely.

While the pixelated look remains, the mechanics were improved and both movement and text skipping feels less sluggish. Most puzzles are more straightforward while still being fun to solve (except one or two occasions where you're just expected to stumble upon some seemingly random location before proceeding).

If you enjoyed Last Door: Season One, even if you don't praise it as highly as other reviews, definitely don't forget about Season Two: it's more than a worthy sequel.

25957069.review:
Season 1 of The Last Door proved to be one of the best horror games I've played in a long time. It stuck with me long after I finished it, the many surprises and revelations rolling around in my head during dark hours. I was anxious to see if Season 2 lived up to expectations, since it was continuing the story along a different path. I've just finished it, and I can barely contain my adoration for what the developers have accomplished with this series.

You take on the role of Dr. John Wakefield, on the trail of his vanished patient Jeremiah Devitt who also happened to be the protagonist of Season 1. Knowing what you know about the events of the first game, the second wastes no time delving into the secrets of the world by sending you on a chase across a nightmare version of Victorian England. Your search will take you to a decaying asylum, a forlorn manor, a distant island, and beyond. In each locale you will uncover clues, puzzle through riddles, and peer into the darkness underpinning the world.

There are no major diversions in the core gameplay from Season 1, really. You navigate interconnected scenes, collect items to use in puzzles, and converse with any useful individuals present. Each episode now has a map you can use to travel between different areas, but all this means is a little more variety in the locales within the episode. It also makes the game feel a little sparser, since you'll be spending less time in a given place as you zip around in search of secrets.

What is different is the pace of the game. Season 2 is a bit longer than Season 1, around 45 minutes to an hour per episode, and that time is a little more guided than before. Whereas Season 1 left you to mostly wander and puzzle out the details of each location yourself, Season 2 has more cutscenes and incidental events to stumble across. There's more going on in each area, and that sometimes means the spooks and the puzzles are more spaced out than before. The connections between episodes are also noticeably rougher, with a few of the jumps coming up in the closing cutscene with not much context.

By episode 2 I wasn't sure if I was liking where it was going or how it was getting there. But by the end of that episode I was hooked, and the game improved to previously unseen heights as it rolled on. For one thing, the puzzles become more intricate and clever further in, especially once you pass the sprawling riddle in episode 2. Season 2 also dispenses with most of the jump scares and stingers of Season 1 in favor of some incredible atmosphere and creeping dread. The stakes of the story are much higher here, and you see that play out in the events that unfold.

I really can't stress enough how good the atmosphere and storytelling are here. Honestly, The Game Kitchen really [i]gets[/i] Lovecraft better than anyone else I've seen in the gaming world. Season 2 takes place in a world where ancient, eldritch forces simply [i]are[/i], where they are clearly a foundation of reality and the little people you meet have simply learned to live with them in their own twisted ways. From start to finish you feel that great and terrible weight, moreso than in Season 1, and the story does not shy away from the ultimate confrontation in the end. The final episode is a triumph of eldritch terror, diving head-first into true cosmic horror and giving life to everything hinted at up to the point in a way that does not disappoint.

Fans of cosmic horror need to have this series at the top of their list. The Last Door captures that feeling of hopelessness in the face of the vast unknowable, while at the same time telling a very human story about temptation and hubris. Don't let the chunky pixel art put you off, for it very effectively leaves just enough to the imagination to make the terrors you face that much more terrible. And the the fantastic sound design more than makes up for any graphical gripes, featuring rich, detailed effects and an orchestral soundtrack that soars when it needs to and unsettles when it can. Rare are the games that can engage your fears and imagination so effectively, and The Last Door should be lauded for standing so tall among them.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

So, these are still good games. They're creepy and atmospheric and they've got closed captioning AND dyslexia-friendly fonts, which is pretty awesome IMO.

Buuuut, maybe because I don't have the same relationship with playing the same games over and over waiting for the new ones to come out, I didn't think it's as good as season one.

1) Although the animation has improved drastically, it seems to be to the detriment of the actual game. There's a loooot of flavor texts missing in this game, including the text for the inspect button. That's.... something that should have been fixed.

2) We don't really know the people we're playing as? Dr Wakefield was introduced briefly in Season 1, but I still don't really understand who Kaufman was supposed to be.

3) Two endings, based on the very last decision you make in-game, and to see them both you have to replay from the beginning of the final episode. What a joke.

Of course, they're still not bad games. Heck, you can even skip the credit sequences. Nice

25708097.review:
After being impressed by Season 1, I was a little worried that Season 2 might be disappointing. To my surprise, Season 2 made the entire series even BETTER. Somehow the developers achieved the near-impossible job of explaining what happened while keeping everything as interesting and scary as in the first season. 

Personally, I liked Season 2 even better because, for me, the story was more emotionally engaging. Season 1 was interesting, but in Season 2 I was actually worried about the good doctor and wished for his success (whatever that means). There was a point in the game where I was devastated. 

Except for a few insignificant bugs, the whole game is excellent in every way--the story, music and atmosphere, and puzzles. I'm really glad that I played this game, and I can't wait for the next game by The Game Kitchen.

24949465.review:
鉴于在一、二季均已在steam发售的情况下,第二季的反响寥寥与第一季的倍受称道形成了令人颇感遗憾的反差,故将这篇测评发表在这里。在一波波怀有精心包装过的恶毒野心而又有大批无知拥护者助长其气焰和势头的文化入侵浪潮的影响下,国内的一些乐于接受新生事物和奉行娱乐至死精神的群体对于天资聪颖的作家洛夫克拉夫特笔下的克苏鲁神话抱有极其荒谬可笑、且与其真意截然相反的印象;尤其是当他们那愚蠢而可悲的认知力迫使他们不得不将自己的精力从急切地想要理解这一被他们可怜的头脑视作高深莫测的体系的天真想法中转移出来,又集中到那些粗俗的、卑劣的、也更加符合他们不愿思考的作风的放荡恶行中时,他们对于这些为他们所厌烦的繁琐陈述所展示出的不屑态度和惯常的玩世不恭之情足以令每一位此类文学的爱好者心灰意冷。可是现在,克苏鲁文化也开始以这些群体能够接受的、同时也与他们粗野的思维模式无比接近的新形式散布着它的影响力、延续着它的生命力。虽然有着晦涩难解的主线和不讨喜的像素外观,但The Game Kitchen的The Last Door绝对算得上是一干洛夫克拉夫特式游戏里的个中翘楚。在我看来,与其说The Last Door系列是一部带有明显复古风格且在剧情设计上独具匠心的点击式解谜游戏,不如称其为一种糅合了摄人心魄的考究音乐和出色的、即使与亚瑟•梅琴笔下的某些骇人故事相比也毫不逊色的恐怖小说的别致艺术品。

故事的一、二季分别围绕哲学教授耶利米·戴维特和他的心理医生约翰·威克菲尔德展开。第一季中,戴维特在一封急件的召唤下探访了故友安东尼·比奇沃思的宅邸,并发现比奇沃思夫妇先后死于非命,随后,在独自前往儿时的寄宿学校以发掘事情的全貌时,他又卷入了来自往日的、更加古老恐怖的奥秘,并将自己的性命也托付给了危险而不可知的命运;第二季中,威克菲尔德医生在其同僚兼好友约翰·考夫曼的协助下,努力地追踪着所有业已失踪的戴维特可能留下的蛛丝马迹,为此他不惜涉足那些可憎梦魇的栖居地和荒蛮可怕、与世隔绝的化外之地。剧情的发展平稳扎实,虽然到了将近结尾的部分有些仓促从而在某些分支的交代上显得略为不明所以,但这一不足挂齿的细小缺陷正如下文将提到的真正意义上或是被某些人想当然的认为成的瑕疵一样,在游戏极高的素质面前都变得黯淡无光。游戏通篇充斥着抑郁悲惨的色彩和黑暗隐匿的感染力,庞杂幽深、阴晦委婉且令人回味无穷的情节和适时的、虽由像素构成但在视觉冲击上毫不含糊的惊悚片断使得The Last Door成为同类游戏中的上乘之作,并在凄美肃穆的配乐的烘衬下得以淋漓尽致地延展补完。爱伦·坡的影子也是显而易见的,在第一季稍前的部分,这种独到的渲染甚至更胜——根据某些观点——洛夫克拉夫特式文学对本作的影响,无论是黑猫还是乌鸦,光是这些元素的存在就足以凸显通篇那阴沉而引人入胜的基调。

尽管它那模糊晦暗的美术风格为不少挑剔者所诟病,我却认为纵使制作组有能力将游戏画面提升一整个档次,也完全没有必要通过这种细腻的粉饰将游戏氛围压低一整个档次;因为极度阴郁的场景所带来的压抑感和若即若离的微妙朦胧感不一定能被3A大作复制,却已被证实可以在这款为许多硬核玩家所嫌恶的像素游戏中得以呈现;而且,我也同意一个说法,那就是制作组其实正是想要通过刻意的暧昧处理来揭示那些阴郁可怖的场景和其中蕴含着的艰深复杂的奥秘。

而与称之为简陋都不为过的画面形成对比,游戏中频繁出现的深奥而冗长的对话以及同样令人提不起兴致的日记、手稿、信件、大部头的虚构典籍和动辄数页的笔记则虽然乍看起来没有什么深切的必要,但在细究之下便会发现,这种将实质上最能昭示通篇来龙去脉并给予相应线索的因素穿插在剧情发展中、甚或直接在解谜过程中的做法其实是无比巧妙的。

章节式的制作流程不可避免地使故事的脉络显得松散而缺乏连贯性,同时也从根本上造成了开篇提及的惊人差距;可这种耐人寻味的做法切实还原了包括我在内的一部分洛夫克拉夫特的读者在阅读其作品时的某些难以阐述的隐晦感觉印象;而且,不应忘记的是,被斯蒂芬·金誉为“可能是用英语写成的最棒的恐怖故事”的《大神潘恩》——追求将情节剖析地细致入微的玩家也许会发现,大神潘恩(The Great God Pan)这一名字也玩味地出现在了第一季第三章中的书店的大门之上——也采用了种看似零碎无比的叙述方式,并且通过它那如雷贯耳的名声证明了只要读者乐意,他们是完全可以与作者的心思相通的;事实上,读过此书的人不难发现,The Last Door中对于帷幕等一系列的设计与书中雷蒙德博士对我们所处的世界的描述是何等相似、Simurg和Pan的形象单纯从精神方面的存在和地位上来说是多么相近,也不需要我提醒你们梅琴的思想在这款游戏中的体现几乎可以与它在洛夫克拉夫特的创作中的渗透程度相比拟。

我本想再抽出些篇幅用以描写游戏中那震撼人心的、即使在我撰写这长篇大论时仍不忘将其循环播放、仔细聆听的幽雅的曲目,但奈何我对音律之事一无所知,并且每每企图将那萦绕心头的无形力量转化为文字时总是深感词穷,所以在此不作表述。我想说的只是,The Last Door能让任何想要体验或重温阅读以洛夫克拉夫特为代表的杰出恐怖大师笔下的精彩文章的人如愿以偿;它的品质和知名度虽完全不成正比,但任何理由都不足以恰当到使如此杰作默默无闻地湮没。

Utterly fantastic. 
I've always been a fan of point and click games, long before I had a beast of a computer to actually run real video games. A staple of this genre has always been the absurd puzzles that have you running around for twenty minutes only to discover you overlooked a key under the doormat. 
The Last Door has great puzzles, a great collection of documents to read, lore to ponder, and memorable, interesting characters. And I never thought a pixel game could be that terrifying.
Best of all is that this is arguably one of the most Lovecraftian games I've ever played (faithful if you will, even if the lore is completely different). It's a good mixture of Lovecraft and Poe (Poe more so in Season 1, Lovecraft in Season 2) so if you happen to be a fan of those authors (or gothic literature in general) then this game is a must have. 
A simple but marvelously well written game.

24265395.review:
The Last Door: Season 2 is an episodic story-driven point-and-click adventure game developed and published by The Game Kitchen consisting of four new episodes and a continuation from where the last game (season) left off, albeit from a different character’s perspective.

In this season, the story follows John Wakefield, the former psychiatrist of Jeremiah Devitt (protagonist from Season 1), in search for Devitt after his sudden disappearance in the previous game. Along his journey, Wakefield is accompanied by his close associate, Herr Doctor Johann Kaufmann, an unfathomable German nobleman who displays a high level of expertise in the understanding of the dark forces that affected Devitt and who aided Wakefield in investigating Devitt's condition previously. Both of these characters play similar roles to Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson; Wakefield is the type of character who asks the questions and Kaufmann is the one providing the answers, except in a more cryptic manner. An issue in the previous game was the lack of memorable characters, and it is safe to say that that is not the case here. The story provides quite a few twists and turns, easily making it one of the main reasons to complete The Last Door: Season 2. It even has two endings which can be triggered by the player’s choice in the last scene. Regardless of the choice, both endings provide a suitable closure to The Last Door saga.

Much like the first game, The Last Door: Season 2 uses the same pixel art for its aesthetics which is simple but surprisingly effective, making it tough to criticise it for as it does not ruin the experience in any way; the pixel hunting (another issue in the first game) has been solved this time with items which look brighter and are easier to spot in the background. On a side by side comparison, the graphics do look polished up compared to the previous game whilst still remaining faithful to the series’ unique visuals. Lighting effects seem to have improved as well. Nevertheless, it goes without saying that its visual presentation might not conform with everyone’s tastes, much like the lack of voice acting. Moreover, both the sound design and soundtrack are well implemented in the world of The Last Door and do their job enough to create a similar atmosphere found in the first game, although, in terms of ambience, it does have some moments where nothing is played in the background which is a bit of a letdown.

The gameplay remains more or less the same as in Season 1; thus, expect your typical point ‘n’ click affair where you move the character around different locations whilst collecting items, occasionally combining, and using them to solve puzzles to advance the story. Just like the first game, many areas at the start of an episode are locked, but these can be unlocked by finding keys or using specific items. One notable (and welcomed) addition in Season 2 is the world map which gives the player more locations to explore in a non-linear fashion, to an extent, rather than being restricted to one single map as in the previous season. This helps giving the game a tad more feeling of exploration and variety. The feeling of any backtracking becoming tedious is absent thanks to the small size of the maps and the quick travel mechanic which immediately transports you to the next scene.

Once again, the puzzle solving is very easy and fairly logical, making it suitable to newcomers to the point ‘n’ click genre. Veterans of the genre will undoubtedly find it very easy though. There is hardly a need of checking a walkthrough at any given point, except maybe of a specific maze-like puzzle which honestly should not take too long to figure it out after some attempts. On the other hand, the advantage of these easy puzzles is that the pace of the story remains consistent without ending up meandering around, frustratingly looking for clues on how to solve a puzzle. The most noticeable improvement between the two seasons is that the variety of puzzles has visibly increased. As a result, Season 2 is longer in length, with around 6-hours to complete it compared to the roughly 4-hours in Season 1.

The Last Door series is well known for its emphasis on tense Lovecraftian horror and disturbing atmosphere, and Season 2 follows the same trend established by Season 1. However, having played the first game, it is hard not to notice how the creepiness was toned down in exchange for, arguably, superior storytelling this time around. Season 2 definitely feels a lot more focused on filling all those gaps left in the story from Season 1 as much as possible, as there are only a handful of scenes as spine-chilling as in the first game throughout the first three episodes. Thankfully, for those who loved the atmosphere of the first game, the last episode is a return to that specific atmosphere fans were accustomed. To provide some context, in the first game there were many moments where certain “supernatural” events would catch you off guard from time to time and created this tense, scary atmosphere as you did not know why those events were occurring initially. There was always a sense of mystery and intrigue. Furthermore, the use of imagery and disturbing backgrounds were also key to their effectiveness. In Season 2, as the story advances, you progressively get to discover, little by little, why these, although not all, events occurred and who is behind them which eventually becomes less terrifying the more you find out. The point I am trying to make is that, personally, I did not feel creeped out by Season 2 as much as I did in the first game which, for me, is somewhat disappointing since that is one of things I hoped the sequel would keep and even improve upon. However, in the end, I strongly feel that Season 2 is superior to the first season as a whole experience due to the small improvements made, here and there, and the better storytelling despite the toned down atmosphere. Do not get me wrong, it still has its petrifying moments, like the ending of the second episode.

In conclusion, The Last Door: Season 2 might lack the overall eeriness of the first game, but it compensates in polished up gameplay, crispier visuals, better variety of puzzles and superior storytelling that provides a satisfactory conclusion to The Last Door saga. Probably not as memorable as the first game, but definitely better as a whole package. Highly recommended to folks who finished the first game, any point 'n' click fans, and those who like Lovecraftian horror stories in general. If you are entirely new to this series, do yourself a favour and grab The Last Door bundle and enjoy the ride.

Are you ready for a spooky unnerving tale of insanity, eldritch horrors, dark secrets, riddles, strange planes of reality, and a crap-ton of evil crows?  Then The Last Door series is the game(s) for you!

I can honestly say that I haven't enjoyed a good adventure game like this in a long time.  The rich and captivating story is one of the best parts of the game, and heavily draws inspiration from the writings of H.P. Lovecraft.  The game also manages to convey a creepy and unsettling atmosphere despite it's low-res 2D graphics, which in my eyes is rather impressive.  The puzzles you are required to solve are very well crafted, and are just the right difficulty to flow smoothly along with the story.

The only thing I don't like about the game is that the music can sometimes drag on for too long, even after a certain sequence has ended.  Also it's important to note that there are one or two code glitches that pop up within the game, something the developers probably didn't catch.  It's not so bad that in disrupts the game's natural flow, it's just something important to keep in mind. 

If you are an H.P. Lovecraft fan, King's Quest fan, or a big puzzle geek, get your wallet and buy this game now.  Trust me, it's worth it.

22510232.review:
A smashing finale to the eldritch saga!  As before, the resolution is so inhumanly low it must lie at the bottom of some unfathomable Stygian pit, reveling in the gelid touch of the rugose abominations that squirm so thickly about it, biding its time, occasionally emitting a liquid chortle . . . Even with pixels so few and -- dare I utter it -- [i][b]cyclopean[/b][/i], it's an evocative style that tells us all we need to know and more; a fuller glimpse, after all, might send our fragile psyches reeling into the oblivion of existential madness!  Having subjected my own frail mind to [i]Season 2[/i], I am compelled to step back and marvel at the heights that can be reached by willfully plummeting into the jagged depths of low fidelity.  The retro experimentation must continue!  

I was very surprised at some of the twists the story took, but very pleased to be so, as it never lost the low, infernal thrum of Lovecraftian horror:  a mode in which suggestion and slowly layered atmosphere predominate over messy vivisection.  Thankfully, the English localization has vastly improved over the first half, leaving us to sort out this dense and intelligent weird tale without the added stumbling block of "accented English."  The puzzles are slightly more complex than in the first season, but never veer far from the easy side of the scale.  It's more about the experience -- the sense of tense exploration and dreaded discovery -- rather than the challenge, anyway.

 An excellent achievement in both low-fi artwork and interactive Lovecraftianism!  An absolute must-play (after you've gone through [i]Season 1[/i], of course)!

I am someone who came to fear sequels and endings to stories.
Especially to strange stories.
I feared Season would be something so different that it would not fit.
How wrong I was.

I played everything from the collector's edition, so I did not had to wait for episodes to come out.
Episode one is really good. Mysterious, diversified, everything was good.
Episode two felt somehow less enjoyable on the overall but still awesome.
Episode three was a bit of an anomaly here. Not really following episode two, not really necessary to get before the last episode.
It was strange, but not the same way as the others, it was disconnected. It is good as its own story but doesn't really fit.

The last episode is the best thing that could have happenned to The Last Door.
A real ending, the real world losing itself in the long lost realm, sought by the characters since the beginning.
And I spoil nothing.
Maybe too much linear, as you can see immediately that you are carried by the story.
The amount of puzzles, some not really interesting ( the fog returns... damn ), is maybe too much.
But I cannot say anything of a story that ends the best manner it could have ended.

The game is more dynamic, with new mechanics ( a map with several locations ), and new background and foreground managment.

Carlos Viola's music is still present and it serves the ambient, and as we go through the game, the story, so well it transported me perhaps more than in the first season. I have no words to describe it in a better manner.

Everything is different but, in a way, it feels just the same.

Season Two brings indeed a great sequel to a great game, and a great closure to a great story.

The Red Curtains just fell on The Last Door.

And all my wishes of success goes to The Game Kitchen.

22165851.review:
The full season has been released a few days ago and...

...holy shit.

If you were a fan of the first season, you are definitely going to enjoy season two. 

The story starts off at where it ended in season one. Instead of playing as Devitt, you now play as his former psychiatrist, Dr Wakefield. In four episodes, the game tells the story of Wakefield searching for Devitt across four different locations. It is during these episodes that you learn about what happened prior to the events of season one -- although most of the flashbacks are only in the final episode. 

IF you thought that season one was too short, you're going to be happy that they fixed that in season two. In season one, you would just stick to one place in season one in every episode. In season two, you can travel to SEVERAL locations on a map in every episode (except for the last one, but given the plot at that time, it's probably best not to go anywhere).

It's been developed by the same group of people and their formula of an amazing season one has been reused in season two. Music is atmospheric and beautiful (as expected) and fits perfectly within the game. Graphics still pixelated but the development team seems to have hit the nail on the head again. The game looks wonderful in general (if you can look past the fact that everything's pixelated) but compared to season one, everything somehow seems prettier. They haven't changed anything important about gameplay (if it ain't broke, don't fix it) but they have added some interesting features, like puzzles.

In short, the game has the same feel to it as season one but the dev team managed to make it more than just a sequel. 

Although it will probably not be as well-known as season one (I only found this game by sheer coincidence), it's still an incredibly well-made game and if you're into the genre, this game is a must-have.

Pros:
- Additional features compared to s1
- Astonishing graphics
- Fantastic music
- Good continuation of story

Cons:
- Few bugs

Rating: Solid 9.5/10 - get it whenever you can.

(Sidenote: I made a guide! It's a walkthrough to the game and contains achievements as well. If you're ever lost, you can take a quick look at it.)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=604795925

22159611.review:
Jest dobrze, nawet bardzo dobrze. :)

Fabuła, która jest kontynuacją sezonu pierwszego, jest nadal doskonała. W tym sezonie wcielamy się w Doktora Wakefielda, który podąża śladem zaginionego protagonisty pierwszej części - Devitta. Zostają rozwiązane luźne wątki i niedomówienia, pierwszej części. Na plus zaliczam też dwa zakończenia, mimo iż decyzję, które zobaczymy, podejmujemy tylko w ostatnich minutach gry. 

Klimat i atmosfera pozostają niezmiennie wyśmienite. Tak samo jak oprawa muzyczna - moim skromnym zdaniem - jest to jedna z najlepszych ścieżek dźwiękowych, jaką miałam przyjemność usłyszeć. Świetnie buduje poczucie zagrożenia i niepokoju. 
Tym razem w grze zwiedzimy, dużo więcej różnorodnych lokacji, od piękniej posiadłości, przez oddaloną od cywilizacji wyspę, aż po miejsce wyjęte wprost z sennego koszmaru. Szczególnie miejscówki w ostatnim rozdziale zasługują na pochwałę.

Zagadki stoją na przyzwoitym poziomie. Nie są za łatwe, ale też nie sprawiają, że zwoje mózgowe parują. Tylko raz zupełnie nie wiedziałam, co należy zrobić i po prostu latałam po całej wyspie, szukając elementu, który popchnie rozgrywkę dalej.
[Spoiler]
Po naprawieniu mechanizmu w latarni i posiadłości Lorda, miały się otworzyć drzwi do sali zabaw pewno chłopca, ale otworzyć się nie chciały (myślałam, że to jakiś błąd w grze).

Trzeba było wrócić na cmentarz, wykopać lusterka spod drzewa i podążyć - pod wspomnianą salę - za pewną postacią. Wtedy drzwi się otwierały.  :szok: [/spoiler]
Nie podobał mi się też leśny labirynt w ostatnim rozdziale. Mimo iż wiedziałam dokładnie, jak należy się kierować (zebrałam wszystkie wskazówki), tylko łut szczęścia zadecydował, że udało mi się przez niego przejść.

Jednokrotne przejście zajęło mi około 7 godzin.

Oceniam tytuł na 8/10

22154624.review:
In brief:  If you like H.P. Lovecraft, buy this game.

In far longer summation. It is rare that I decide to write a review of a game, but in the case of The Last Door Season 2, I am pleased to make an exception to this policy.  I do not speak idly when I say that this is one of the best games I have played in the last few years.  Certainly the graphical style is not to everyone's taste, but I found that it fit the game in a way I cannot quite describe.  Yet I fear I am rambling, so allow me to lay out, in a concise a manner as possible, why I liked this game.  It is of course, not completely without flaws, such as the occasional moment where the game behaved strangely when I was picking up objects (such as the umbrella in Episode 3), but these are the pettiest of quibbles. 

I. The atmosphere.  This game has a superb atmosphere and sense of place that draws the player into the world and the story. It builds suspense, and manages to be unnerving with a graphical style that I am afraid to admit I initially sneered at.   
II. The story. Naturally, one should play Season 1 before Season 2, in order to experience the story.  It is taught, well crafted, and creates a fascinating world and lore all its own.  It is perhaps the best Lovecraftian I have ever seen in a game (and that includes the vaunted Bloodborne).
III. The music.  The soundtrack to this game is one of the best I have ever heard.  While, as with all things, this is a manner of taste, I found the music to be excellently composed, and to fit the mood of the game to a T.  

In conclusion, to anyone who enjoys Point & Click Adventures, horror games, H.P. Lovecraft, or even classical music, I must recommend this game.   During a time where Steam is increasinly deluged by blindingly unoriginal two bit horror games, it is a joy to see something like this.

22149292.review:
Slightly weaker than Season 1, but still an amazing story-driven horror adventure game. If you're looking for Lovecraft, Edgar Poe or Kafka-type unease, madness and horror, look no further than The Last Door. And play both seasons chronologically.

Season 2 seems to be a definite finale to the storyline that began in Season 1 (of course, with possible new games set in the same universe) and answers all the questions that needed answers, without ruining the unspeakbleness of horrors you encounter, leaving them still beyond your understanding. The story feels trailing off guidelessly at times, unlike Season 1, where it always felt like it was more bits of the same story. But it's still interesting, told in a great way that mixes story and puzzle bits without breaking the pace all that much. There are few moments where I felt that I was starting to wonder aimlessly not noticing a necessary item/dialogue trigger to move the game forward, but those moments were rare and didn't ruin the experience in any way. There were also several simple non-game-breaking bugs that will probably get fixed soon. With only big complaint remaining from the previous Season - that you can't really skip scenes if you're replaying the episode and want to find something you might've missed or just to re-experience specific moments. Still, amazing atmospheric horror story game.

I'm really surprise that this hardly got any attention in the "horror gaming genre" in YouTube. (Only Ken plays it) But I'm sure, that this game would be one of the best pixelated-horror experiences you ever play. Definitely worth it. The graphics are intentionally bad, but that's what makes the game so good. Limited vision is one of the best mechanics in pixelated-horror games because as you can't see what is it, you get freaked out. The music is also spectacular and it really sets the mood of the scenario (Though it will be better to reuse some of the pieces from season 1? So to get some nostalgia kicking  in?) And most importantly, Story. It is what drives Wakefield deeper into the mystery; It is what makes Wakefield's motive of keenly investigating such a case; and It is why you should play this. Definitely worth it. Really want to see Markiplier playing it.

(And it would be better to release a Mac version as well in the future)
(EDIT: 29 Mar 2016. Mac version is released. Very appreciated. Rate 10/10)

40057621.review:
Once again: creepy atmosphere interspersed with sheer madness.

I can actually say most of the things I have mentioned in my review of the first season here too.
The presentation is extremely well-done despite its seemingly obsolete graphics. Actually, they support the dreadful setting considerably.
The sounds and music are also placed and paced extraordinarily suitably. That is what I would call brilliant design!
Probably the best part is the story, albeit confusing at times. But this is of course part of the excitement. What never stops is the tension which is also supported by twists, different approaches and game elements I would not have expected from a point and click title.
I also enjoyed the last part where we learn more about what happened before season 1 and about the motifs of the characters involved.

If you like horror point-and-click games and especially if you enjoyed the first season, you do not need to look further! I would say it is even better than the first part, so it receives an 88 % rating from me.
